tossups.question: Mario Vargas Llosa’s book The Temptation of the Impossible is about this other book, as is David Bellos’ The Novel of the Century. The author of this novel set its partial manuscript aside for almost twenty years, during which it was almost destroyed by a mob that had invaded his house. Contemporary reviews of this novel criticized its use of counterfactuals, such as asking whether rain would have changed the outcome of the Battle of Waterloo. This novel was extremely popular with Confederate soldiers, who sometimes referred to themselves as (*) “Lee’s” versions of the title characters. This novel’s protagonist flees to a location founded by Martin Verga called Petit-Picpus by hiding in a coffin, aided by a man named Fauchelevant, who he had earlier rescued from under a cart. For 10 points, name this novel in which Javert pursues former convict Jean Valjean.

During this election’s primaries, one Republican was forced to bow out after he erroneously claimed to have been a combat marine in the Korean War, while two Democrats ended their campaigns after describing New York as “Hymietown” and conducting an extramarital affair on a yacht called the “Monkey Business.” This election’s primaries thus ended without Pat Robertson or Rev. Jesse Jackson. Ads depicting the losing candidate riding a (*) tank and a murderer who had killed while on furlough were crafted by Lee Atwater; the latter “Willie Horton” ad did much to doom the loser’s campaign. The winning candidate’s failure to fulfill his pledge "Read my lips: no new taxes” sank his re-election campaign. For 10 points name this election, which saw the defeat of Michael Dukakis by George H. W. Bush.
tossups.answer: Presidential election of 1988 (accept equivalents, including anything mentioning the election of George H.W. Bush before the name is read) <Ed. JM>

tossups.question: A class of these compounds with two imine groups is known as NacNac. “Innocent” examples of these compounds are ignored in Enemark-Feltham notation. One of these compounds used in several asymmetric epoxidations is named salen. The CBC method classifies these compounds by their valence into types labeled L, X, and Z. Their interactions are described by the (*) angular overlap model. The size of these compounds is measured by their cone angle. The letter mu is used to notate the bridging types of these compounds, and the number of bonds they can make is called their denticity. For 10 points, name these molecules that bind to a central metal atom in coordination complexes.

Some legends suggest that this figure was born fully grown and then ate his parents, although other legends call him “thrice born,” due to the natural and man-made manifestations of the force over which he has power. This figure is worshipped in the three aspects Pavaka, Pavimana, and Suchi, and therefore is often depicted as having three (*) heads, although he is sometimes depicted with two heads to symbolize the destructive and helpful aspects of his power. In the Vedas, this figure is said to reign supreme on earth, as opposed to the heavens and the sky, which are left to his brothers. In some legends, this figure is the father of Skanda, though in almost all legends he is depicted as having red skin, is conveyed by a ram, and has an insatiable appetite for ghee, or clarified butter. For 10 points name this twin of Indra, the Vedic god of fire.

This author wrote a play in which a woman seeks permission from her gay former lover to publish his forty year old love letters. This author included the line "Certain women should be struck regularly, like gongs" in a play in which two characters who hope to never quarrel again come up with the phrase "Solomon Isaacs" to signal two minutes of silence. In that play by this author, the divorced couple Elyot and (*) Amanda have side-by-side hotel balconies while honeymooning with new spouses. This author of Song at Twilight wrote another play in which Madame Arcati, a medium, is partly responsible for the haunting of Charles Condomine by the ghost of his first wife. For 10 points, name this English playwright of Private Lives and Blithe Spirit.

An unfinished text by this thinker cautions against method and advocates introspection into “perceptual faith.” One essay by this thinker criticizes operational thinking before outlining a scenario in which “science’s agile and improvisatory thought … will once more become philosophy.” This philosopher described a black line in a portrait that dislocates as it passes behind the subject in his analysis of a certain painter’s “lived perspective.” This author of “Eye and Mind” and (*)“Cézanne’s Doubt” argued that humans experience space and time as “unlimited milieus,” due to our symbolic behavior. A book by this author of The Structure of Behavior rejects empiricism and idealism for their “unquestioned belief in the world,” in favor of a method used by Husserl. For 10 points, name this French author of The Visible and the Invisible and The Phenomenology of Perception.

One character created by this author is described as having “so much authority that he could have drawn fish out of the sea simply by calling their names.” That character weighs almost as much as a horse and has a shirt made for him out of bridal linen. Another character created by this author is transformed into a tarantula for disobedience, distracting attention from the title character of a story who is questioned in Latin while captive in a (*) chicken coop. This author wrote a short story about a girl who is forced to become a prostitute to repay a debt to her grandmother; that character, Innocent Erendira, also appears in this author’s best known novel. For 10 points, name this author of “The Handsomest Drowned Man in the World” and “A Very Old Man with Enormous Wings,” whose short story “Leaf Storm” is the first appearance of the town of Macondo.
tossups.answer: Gabriel Garcia Marquez [prompt on partial answers, prompt on Gabo] <Ed. DS>

tossups.question: In one painting, this artist used a group of green undulating lines and blue wisps separated by several converging diagonals to represent music. This artist studied the ideas of painter Arthur Wesley Dow at the University of Virginia before receiving a scholarship to study at the Art Students League of New York. The work of Charles Demuth influenced a painting by this artist which depicts the building (*) she lived in “with sunspots.” While living at the Shelton Hotel, this artist painted a precisionist depiction of the Radiator Building, and was often photographed by Alfred Stieglitz. For 10 points, name this artist who painted a lot of New York skyscrapers prior to moving to New Mexico, and who is better known for subjects like horse skulls and flowers.

This woman figures prominently in recent popular histories by Antonia Fraser and Alison Weir. According to the latter, this woman became the first female ambassador in European history after the death of her first husband, Arthur. As regent of England, this woman’s rousing speech to the Earl of Surrey’s forces is credited with inspiring them to win the battle of (*) Flodden on behalf of her second husband. Her insistence that her first husband’s youth prevented him from having sex with her before he died allowed her to marry again after a decree from Pope Julius II. In 1527 Pope Clement VII, then a prisoner of this woman’s nephew Charles V, would later refuse to annul that marriage, compelling her husband to take drastic steps to put her aside so he could marry Anne Boleyn. For 10 points, name this queen of England, mother of Mary I and first wife of Henry VIII.
tossups.answer: Catherine of Aragon [Prompt on Catherine] <Ed. JM>

tossups.question: Glucose changes the plasticity of cells called tanycytes, which regulate the transport of hormones in and out of this structure. Tertiary hypothyroidism is due to defects in this structure. A genetic disorder affecting this structure which causes anosmia and hypogonadism is Kallmann syndrome. Damage affecting the production of a hormone in this structure is one cause of diabetes (*) insipidus. Lesions on the suprachiasmatic nucleus of this structure impair circadian rhythms, while vasopressin and oxytocin are produced in the paraventricular nucleus. For 10 points, name this bridge between the nervous and endocrine systems, named for its location below a different part of the brain.
tossups.answer: hypothalamus [do NOT accept or prompt on “thalamus”]

tossups.question: The speaker of a poem by this author claims “writing is exciting,” and incorporates calls Mel Allen made of the title sport. That poem by this writer opens with the parenthetical statement, “Suggested by post-game broadcasts.” In another poem by this author of “Baseball and Writing,” the speaker describes a town with “eight stranded whales,” where the only danger is a man “gilding the solid-pointed star.” This poet describes the “autocrats among us” as (*)“‘literalists of the imagination’” in a poem that was cut down to three lines in a revision for a poetry collection. This poet of “The Steeple-Jack” wrote a poem in which the title activity can conjure “imaginary gardens with real toads in them.” That poem by this author begins with the speaker declaring “I, too, dislike” the title activity. For 10 points, name this American modernist poet of “Poetry.”
tossups.answer: Marianne Moore [or Marianne Craig Moore] <Ed. JO>

tossups.question: A volcanic rock rich in this element display thin blades known as spinifex structure and is komatiite. This is the lighter of the two elements that are found alongside the double chains in amphiboles. This element’s silicate mineral is forsterite, while fayalite is the silicate of another element that interchanges with this element along a solid solution series. (*) Peridotite is an igneous rock with a high concentration of this element. The carbonate mineral dolomite contains calcium and this element, and this element’s hydrous sulfate is known as epsomite. Cations of this element and calcium are present in hard water. Rocks and minerals rich in this element and iron, such as olivine, are termed mafic. For 10 points, name this alkaline earth metal, with atomic number 12 and symbol Mg.
tossups.answer: magnesium [or Mg before it is read]

tossups.question: Frank Leslie's Illustrated Newspaper revealed that byproducts from the liquor industry were used in the production of an adulterated bluish form of this substance in 1850s New York. A Cuban national hero who broke the world record for producing this substance was honored by a marble statue and a full-page obituary in Granma. Pottery residues indicate that this substance was used by humans in the 7th millennium BCE, challenging the theory that this substance and wool were first used in the secondary (*) products revolution. Edward Jenner invented the smallpox vaccine after observing people who got a similar disease while producing this substance. Margaret Thatcher became known as a “snatcher” of this substance for ending its free provision to schoolchildren. For 10 points, name this substance produced by Fidel Castro’s favorite cow, White Udder.

This deity’s first children had names meaning either “muddy” or “hairy,” and were sometimes depicted with a red sash and curls. The twelve-day Zagmuk and Akitu festivals celebrated the defeat of this deity. This deity opposed her husband’s plan to kill their descendants for making too much noise, but later created eleven monsters, including the (*) mušḫuššu and the scorpion man, to avenge his death. This deity gave the Tablet of Destinies to her son and consort Kingu after the death of her first husband, Abzu. This deity was killed by a god who filled her belly with wind and fashioned the heavens and the earth from halves of her corpse. For 10 points, name this serpentine Babylonian goddess of the primordial salt sea, who was defeated by Marduk in the Enuma Elish.

This man organized a wave of protests using rubber ducks as their emblem, due to their target having bought a house in France for his pet ducks. This man was brought to court on charges of embezzlement after protests in 2011, and splashed with green dye during another political campaign. This man became famous after running an opposition-oriented LiveJournal blog. This man lost his first mayoral election to Sergei (*) Sobyanin, and led protests after the arrests of Pussy Riot. This man was once again arrested after planning a wave of protests striking all of Russia’s major cities in 2017. For 10 points, name this Russian opposition leader with plans to run against Vladimir Putin in Russia’s next election.

After his death, one of these people’s remains were stuffed into a cannon and shot toward Poland after he was assassinated while drunk on a sleigh ride. That one of these people established a capital at Tushino and married Marina Mniszech. Another of these people was nicknamed “The Thief of Pskov,” and rose to power at the head of a band of cossacks. The first of these people was alleged to be a defrocked monk named Grigory Otrepiev by a (*) Mussorgsky opera in which he was the main villain. These people impersonated a man who died by having an epileptic seizure while playing with a knife, according to an investigation by Vasily Shuisky. For 10 points, name these pretenders to the Russian throne during the Time of Troubles.
tossups.answer: False Dmitrys [accept pseudo-Demetriuses; prompt on rulers of Russia, pretenders to the Russian throne, etc.] <JM>

tossups.question: Gavan Green has controversially argued that one language in this country lacks syllable onsets. Initiated Lardil men in this country spoke a language with only two pronouns, “me” and “not me,” and five airstream mechanisms, including a series of four nasal clicks. In this home to the Arrernte and Damin languages, speech taboos for women in mourning led to the development of the Yolngu and Warlpiri sign languages. The dialect of (*) English spoken by indigenous people in this country shares some features with Bislama and Tok Pisin, while the majority dialect uses the idiom “she’ll be apples” for “it’ll be alright.” That dialect in this country lowers the diphthong in “day,” so many Americans hear it as “die.” For 10 points, name this country home to a dialect of English colloquially known as Strine, and numerous Aboriginal languages.

This composer wrote a toccata for piano that begins with the repetition of a D exchanged between the two hands, with the left hand also playing the D the octave below. A solo cornet plays a quiet ascending D-major, second inversion triad, followed by a descending A-major triad, to begin a suite by this composer. This composer’s sixth piano concerto is unfinished, while the climax of his second piano concerto is marked (*) “Colossale.” This composer’s sixth through eighth piano sonatas are his “War Sonatas.” This composer intended his first symphony to sound like what Haydn would have written. This composer’s fourth piano concerto was written for just the left hand, and he included sleigh bells in the “Troika” section of one of his suites. For 10 points, name this Soviet composer of Peter and the Wolf and the Lieutenant Kije suite.

In 2015, this player’s wife said this player’s team got “screwed per the usual” after this player’s team lost a Thursday night game because a facemask call allowed Aaron Rodgers to throw a Hail Mary. In this player’s rookie season, while playing with a separated shoulder, he threw a touchdown against the Cleveland Browns as time expired. A popular meme features this NFL player with the phrase “that’s a nice lead there. It’d be a shame if someone made a comeback,” which references this player’s eight fourth quarter comebacks in 2016. This player was the number 1 quarterback in the high school class of 2006 before he played with Knowshon Moreno (*) at Georgia where, in 2009, he became the first overall NFL draft pick. This player has played with other offensive players like Golden Tate and Calvin Johnson in his pro career. As of writing, the largest contract in NFL history belongs to--for 10 points--what current Detroit Lions starting quarterback?

The Bouc-Wen model describes this phenomenon for structural systems. Losses in inductors and transformers are due to eddy currents and this phenomenon. Jumps between stable and unstable branches of a subcritical pitchfork bifurcation cause this phenomenon, with respect to the parameter. A model of this phenomenon uses nonideal relays; that model is the Preisach model. Signals can be “debounced” using a (*) Schmitt trigger, a device exhibiting this behaviour. Plots of current versus voltage for a memristor and plots of magnetization versus magnetic field for a ferromagnet show this phenomenon’s namesake loop. For 10 points, name this phenomenon, in which state depends on history.

(TB) Four women painted by this artist are the subject of a Donna M. Lucey book, whose cover features this artist’s portrait of Elizabeth Winthrop Chanler. The husband of a friend and patron of this artist said "It looks like hell, but it looks like you," in response to a portrait by this artist depicting her with cradling arms and a string of pearls around her waist. This artist depicted a Shakespearean actress in a beetle-wing dress raising a crown above her head. This artist of Isabella Stewart Gardner and Ellen (*) Terry as Lady Macbeth also depicted a sexy Scottish woman in a purple sash in his portrait of Lady Agnew of Lochnaw. This artist revised a work which originally depicted the right strap of a black gown scandalously slipping from the shoulder of Pierre Gautreau's extremely pale wife. For 10 points, name this artist of Portrait of Madame X.

bonuses.leadin: Answer the following about tuning. For 10 points each:
parts: An A pitched at 440 hertz is played by this double reed woodwind instrument to tune the orchestra.

In this class of tuning system, intervals are expressed in exact ratios of small, positive integers. For example, a perfect fifth is a ratio of 3 to 2 and a perfect fourth is a ratio of 4 to 3. It is based on the harmonic series.

This term denotes a very small interval that arises from constructing a pitch class two different ways in just intonation. The syntonic type equals 81/80, and represents the interval between four perfect fifths and two octaves, plus a major third.

bonuses.leadin: The author of this book legendarily escaped from Nazi Germany without any of his books, leading him to write it without direct reference to any of the texts he was discussing. For 10 points,
answer: Mimesis: The Representation of Reality in Western Literature
parts: Name this work, described by biographer Harry Levin as an “imaginary museum,” the magnum opus of literary critic Eric Auerbach. It begins with a chapter on “Odysseus’ Scar.”

Mimesis was written during during World War II while Auerbach was living in this country. A contemporary author from this country wrote about a well-digger’s romance with a travelling actress in his 2017 novel The Red-Haired Woman, the follow up to A Strangeness in my Mind.
The only other German writer analyzed in Mimesis is this author, whose play Intrigue and Love forms the basis of the 17th chapter. This author also wrote William Tell.

bonuses.leadin: This task can be accomplished through motifs such as the basic leucine zipper domain. For 10 points each:
answer: DNA binding [accept deoxyribonucleic acid binding; accept a descriptive answer]
parts: Name this task, that usually involves contact with the major or minor grooves. The B recognition element is a common site of this task.

DNA binding domains are found in factors that aid in this process, where RNA polymerases synthesize messenger RNA from a DNA template. The TATA box commonly signals the starting point of this process.

This family of transcription factors, which bind to the minor groove of the DNA double helix, share a DNA-binding domain sequence with, and are named after, the testes determining factor. The second member of this family is a Yamanaka factor.

bonuses.leadin: Answer the following about philosophical paradoxes. For 10 points each:
answer: Zeno of Elea [do NOT accept “Zeno of Citium”] <HB>
parts: This philosopher’s namesake “ass” is a donkey that is equally hungry and thirsty, but cannot choose between eating hay and drinking water because the donkey is equidistant from the two objects.

This paradox from set theory says that considering an ordinal number of the set of the ordinal numbers creates a contradiction because, under the definition of a Von Neumann ordinal, the ordinal number would itself be a set, which is impossible. The New Foundations set theory creates a work around to this paradox.
This Ancient Greek philosopher from Elea created a paradox about Achilles and a tortoise and another paradox where a moving arrow is stationary at any given moment.

bonuses.leadin: A graph has this property if and only if it has an ear decomposition. For 10 points each:
answer: transpose graph [or converse graph; or reverse graph; accept descriptive answers like every edge is reversed]
parts: Name this property that describes a directed graph with a path in both directions between any two vertices. Kosaraju and Tarjan name linear time algorithms to partition a directed graph into components with this property.

Kosaraju’s and Tarjan’s algorithms both use this traversal algorithm, which fully explores each vertex before backtracking. It can be implemented recursively or iteratively using a stack, and it is often contrasted with breadth-first search.

Kosaraju’s algorithm runs DFS twice, once on the original graph G and once on this graph of G. The algorithm relies on the fact that this graph has the same strongly connected components of G, but its source nodes correspond to G’s sink nodes.

bonuses.leadin: While Kendrick Lamar’s most recent album is DAMN, To Pimp a Butterfly almost certainly has more literary references. Answer the following about them. For 10 points each:
answer: Toni Morrison (the novel is The Bluest Eye) <Ed. HB>
parts: Probably the most straightforward reference is with the track “King Kunta,” whose title refers to Kunta Kinte, the protagonist of this novel by Alex Haley.
Kendrick’s track “The Blacker the Berry” is the name of a 1929 novel by this African-American author, whose fourth and fifth parts are titled for a “rent party” and a “pyrrhic victory.”

On the track “Complexion (A Zulu Love),” Rapsody raps “Color of your skin, color of your eyes / That’s the real blues, baby, like you met Jay’s baby,” a possible reference to this author’s novel about Pecola Breedlove.

bonuses.leadin: Subject to this condition, all solutions to Maxwell’s equations satisfy the wave equation given in terms of the potentials, though this condition still leaves a scalar degree of freedom. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this partial gauge condition, which sets the divergence of the [emphasize] four-potential equal to zero.

The Lorenz gauge is Lorentz invariant, which means that solutions in one inertial reference frame hold in all inertial reference frames, making it useful in this physical theory that predicts time dilation and length contraction.
The electric and magnetic potentials of a point charge in arbitrary motion can be calculated using these deceptively simple expressions, which are given in terms of the retarded position.

bonuses.leadin: Answer these questions about the work of your favorite sociologist, Robert K. Merton. For 10 points each:
answer: “Standing on the shoulders of giants” [accept “nanos gigantum humeris insidentes”] <Ed. HB>
parts: Merton developed this theory to show how society encouraged people to conform. Merton said that when individuals have a gap between their goals and their current status, the namesake phenomenon occurs.
Along with the latent function, this “function” was formulated by Merton. This function represents the consequences people expect from an action in Merton’s structural functionalist paradigm.

Merton wrote a work sometimes called a “Shandean postscript” that investigates the origin of this title phrase. This phrase was used by Newton to explain how discoveries depended on the work of predecessors.

bonuses.leadin: These neutral compounds exist in equilibrium with their dimers in a Wanzlick equilibrium. For 10 points each:
parts: Name these compounds, whose central divalent atom of these species is in the singlet state in the type named for Fischer. The central atom of these compounds contains only 6 valence electrons.
This carbene can be formed from the photolytic cleavage of diazomethane. This simplest carbene is named like an alkene, even though its properties are clearly different.
The carbon in this kind of carbene is in the triplet state. Examples of this kind of carbene include Tebbe’s reagent after activation by a Lewis base.

bonuses.leadin: In 1578, the disastrous battle of Al Qasr Quivir put this country into a succession crisis, as its king had died in battle and had no heirs. For 10 points each:
answer: Henrique or Henry [theoretically the only, though accept Henrique [or Henry] the First or Henrique [or Henry] the Chaste or Henrique o Casto]
parts: Name this country, which was forced to turn to the last surviving son of Manuel I, who in 1578 was close to sixty-six years old.

This man succeeded Sebastian as king of Portugal, and is sometimes called the “Cardinal King.” This man was also a priest and had no heirs, so he attempted to get a papal dispensation to marry and father one anyway.
Ultimately, the throne of Portugal was taken over by Philip II of Spain, Henry’s nephew, ending this dynasty of Portuguese rulers, which started with John I the Bastard in 1385.

bonuses.leadin: In a work of this type, the title character learns that Mr. Trappe is blackmailing “the Mistress” of Linendale, with whom she later flees. For 10 points each:
answer: Frederick Douglass [or the Life and Narrative of Frederick Douglass; or Frederick Augustus Washington Bailey]
parts: Name this type of literary work, exemplified by The Bondwoman’s Narrative. In another work of this type, the title person bites Mr. Covey’s hand before he escapes to New Bedford.
This abolitionist published the Narrative of [his] Life and three slave narratives, in which he related his fight with Mr. Covey.

This literary critic edited The Bondwoman’s Narrative for publication in 2002. This Harvard professor analyzed the title practice of wordplay in prominent works of African-American literature in The Signifying Monkey.

bonuses.leadin: This line may have been inspired by a quote from Bassanio in The Merchant of Venice. For 10 points each,
answer: Each man kills the things he loves [accept either Yet or For before Each, accept “(And) all men kill the thing they love”]
parts: Give this repeated line from an 1897 poem. This line was inspired by the execution of Charles Thomas Wooldridge, who was hanged for murdering his wife Nell and who was imprisoned alongside this line’s author.

This author of “The Ballad of Reading Gaol” was sentenced to hard labour after being found guilty of “gross indecency” with men like Alfred Douglas, whose father proved in court that this man was a “posing somdomite.”

Wilde took advantage of the rules which let prisoners write letters by addressing Alfred Douglas in this Latin-titled work, which took him three months to complete. While largely a love letter, it also accuses Douglas of various misdeeds and compares the author to Christ.

bonuses.leadin: Completed in 1910 for its namesake businessman, this house made of Roman brick has horizontal rooflines, overhanging eaves, and 174 art-glass windows. For 10 points each:
answer: ukiyo-e [prompt on woodblock prints or I guess Japanese art]<Ed. DS>
parts: Name this house located in Hyde Park, which is considered to exemplify its creator’s Prairie style.
This architect designed the Robie House, in addition to designing New York’s Guggenheim museum and Fallingwater.

Wright was a huge fan of this art form, which he bought on his trips to their home country and sold at a profit in the United States. He often advised his clients to buy this type of art from him, explaining that it looked particularly good on his walls.

bonuses.leadin: For 10 points each, answer some questions about the influence of Greek sculpture on modern culture.
answer: Boxer at Rest [or Terme Boxer, or Boxer of the Quirinal, also accept Pugilist at Rest]
fashion design [accept stuff like clothing design or dressmaking] <DS>
parts: Myron’s Discobolus, or “Discus Thrower,” appears in the opening of a documentary made by this filmmaker about the 1936 Summer Olympics. This director also made The Triumph of the Will.

This bronze sculpture inspired a Thom Gunn short story narrated by a brain-damaged former soldier. That character praises this sculpture’s sense of “suggestion of weari­ness and philosophical resignation,” suggesting that it may represent a man named Theogenes, who beat 425 men to death.

Mariano Fortuny used the Charioteer of Delphi statue as the basis for a 1907 creation called the “Delphos,” which included an adjustable cord. That creation, which has a variant called the “Peplos,” has been credited with helping to elevate this discipline to the status of art.

bonuses.leadin: During its time as an independent Republic, much of this state’s affairs were guided by the shadowy “Arlington Junto,” which masterminded the Haldimand negotiations, an attempt to enfold this region into its Northern neighbor. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this state, in which an independent republic was declared with its “capital” at Catamount Tavern, where the organizers were drinking at the time.

A key figure in the Arlington Junto was this man, who spent several years as a British prisoner in no small part due to his capture of Fort Ticonderoga alongside Benedict Arnold in 1775. His atheism prevented him from holding formal political office.
The capture of Fort Ticonderoga was effected when Benedict Arnold built a “greenwood navy” on this lake on the Vermont-New York border, which adjoins the much smaller Lake George.

bonuses.leadin: Answer the following about the most topographically thrilling region of the United States, downstate Illinois. For 10 points each:
parts: Southern Illinois is home to this floodplain of the Mississippi River, which also encompasses some of the St. Louis metro area. This region was a center of pre-Columbian settlement, containing cities such as Cahokia.

Southern Illinois’ Hicks Dome is one of a strangely linear series of igneous landforms named for the 38th parallel. That linearity has led to speculation that they were formed by one of these geological features, another one of which was responsible for the uplift of the Hawaiian Islands.

The Southern Illinois town of Cairo [Care-oh] is located at the confluence of the Mississippi and this other major American river, which flows through cities such as Pittsburgh and forms the border between its namesake state and Kentucky.

bonuses.leadin: Answer the following about a dynastic crisis in 1st century China. For 10 points each:
answer: Emperor Ai [accept Xiaoai; or Liu Xin; prompt on Liu]
parts: The dynastic crisis began after this homosexual emperor unsurprisingly failed to produce an heir. His lover, Dong Xian, attempted to seize power after his death.

After the empire ran through a few more emperors, mostly infants, this usurper seized power. He imposed a new system of weights and measures and founded the Xin Dynasty, which fell to rebels after a flood of the Yellow River.
After the fall of Wang Mang, China was reunited under a restoration of this dynasty. This dynasty succeeded the Qin and was founded by Liu Bang in the 3rd century BCE.

bonuses.leadin: This award was given in 2017 to A Horse Walks Into a Bar, which was written by David Grossman and translated by Jessica Cohen. For 10 points,
answer: Man Booker International Prize [do NOT accept or prompt on “Man Booker Prize”]
parts: Name this award for best novel in translation. It was formerly given every two years to highlight an author's overall contribution to literature.
David Grossman hails from this country, which is also home to the very interesting graphic novelist Rutu Modan. Another author from this country, Shmuel Agnon, won the Nobel in 1966.

Also nominated for the 2017 Booker International Prize was this Israeli author of Judas. This author, who chronicled his family history in A Tale of Love and Darkness, has been called a traitor by some Israelis for founding the NGO Peace Now.

bonuses.leadin: It always consists of the touching with oil of the eyes, ears, nostrils, lips, hands, and feet, and can sometimes involve similar application to the small of the back or the groin, though never for men. For 10 points each:
answer: Waldensians [or followers of Peter Waldo] <Ed. JM>
parts: Name this Sacrament of the Catholic Church.

According to the Catholic Encyclopedia, the principal Biblical justification for the Anointing of the Sick comes from the fifth chapter of this book, alleged to have been written by the brother of Jesus.

The same Catholic Encyclopedia suggests that Anointing the Sick was denounced by this heretical sect. This sect, which flourished in the late 1100s in the Piedmont of France, favored extreme renunciation of wealth.

bonuses.leadin: Answer the following about royals who were assassinated by Serbian nationalists. For 10 points each,
answer: May [or May Coup; or May Laws] <JM>
parts: This Serbian spy was responsible for killing King Alexander I of Serbia and his wife Draga. He gained the nickname by which he is most often known from his “bullish” appearance and led the Black Hand.
A more famous royal figure assassinated by Serbian nationalists was this Archduke, the heir to the Austrian throne, who was assassinated in Sarajevo.
The coup in which Alexander I was killed is named for this month. This month also names a series of anti-Semitic laws passed by Alexander III of Russia.
